	To help address our liquidity risk, on May&#160;20, 2015, we completed a $31.0&#160;million capital restructuring transaction that addressed two fundamental areas: (a)&#160;deleveraging the balance sheet and (b) providing new working capital.&nbsp;&nbsp;As part of the capital restructure, we amended our credit agreement and other notes payable by (i) reducing our minimum cash requirement by $2.5&#160;million, thus making this cash available for operational needs, (ii) modifying certain short-term financial covenants to maintain compliance and (iii)&#160;amending our unsecured subordinated seller notes to convert 50% or $8.5 million of the outstanding principal and accrued interest into preferred stock and warrants and reduce the applicable interest rate from 12.0% to 1.5% on the remaining balance through 2016.&nbsp;&nbsp;The capital restructure improved our liquidity by selling shares of preferred stock and warrants for a total of $31.0&#160;million ($22.5&#160;million in cash and $8.5&#160;million in converted subordinated notes).&nbsp;&nbsp;The proceeds received were used to make an accelerated principal payment of $10.0&#160;million under our credit agreement and pay fees and expenses incurred of approximately $1.9&#160;million.&nbsp;&nbsp;The remaining $10.6&#160;million was available for content investment and working capital needs.&nbsp;&nbsp;By reducing our debt balances and the applicable interest rate on the unsecured subordinated seller notes for two years, our future, annual cash interest expense has been reduced by approximately $2.0&#160;million.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	We have taken actions to improve our operating results and Adjusted EBITDA in 2016 by exiting certain non-core operations that have been generating losses.&nbsp;&nbsp;During December 2015, we approved and started implementing a plan to close our Acacia catalog operations (see Note 3,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Segment Information
</FONT>
	).&nbsp;&nbsp;We are also exploring various financing alternatives, which includes raising additional capital and/or refinancing our existing senior debt.&nbsp;&nbsp;There can be no assurances that we will be able to secure additional capital or be able to refinance our senior debt.&nbsp;&nbsp;While our ability to meet our commitments is not dependent upon these efforts, if we were to complete one of these transactions, it would help to address our liquidity risk.&nbsp;&nbsp;We believe that our current financial position combined with our 2016 forecasted operational results and management efforts will be sufficient to meet our commitments. However, there can be no assurances that we will be successful in realizing improved results from operations including improved adjusted EBITDA, generating sufficient cash flows from operations necessary to meet our future covenant requirements, or agreeing with vendors on revised payment terms.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-SIZE:9PT;">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	52
</P>
<HR STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS;WIDTH:100%;">
<A NAME="eolPage53"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-SIZE:1PT;">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-LEFT:10.27%;TEXT-INDENT:-10.27%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<TABLE BORDER="0" CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; WIDTH:100%;">
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="WIDTH:10.27%;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	NOTE 2.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
	SUMMARY OF SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN BOLD;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Use of Estimates
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	The preparation of our consolidated financial statements in conformity with U.S. GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the financial statements.&nbsp;&nbsp;The significant areas requiring the use of management estimates are related to provisions for lower-of-cost or market inventory write-downs, accounts receivable allowances and provision for doubtful accounts and sales returns reserves, valuation of deferred taxes, valuation of warrants, goodwill impairments, and ultimate projected revenues of our film library, which impact amortization of investments in content and related impairment assessments.&nbsp;&nbsp;Although these estimates are based on management&#8217;s knowledge of current events and actions management may undertake in the future, actual results may ultimately differ materially from those estimates.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Revenues and Receivables
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-LEFT:4.54%;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Revenue Recognition
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Revenue is recognized upon meeting the recognition requirements of the Financial Accounting Standards Board Accounting Standards Codification (or
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	ASC
</FONT>
	)
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	926
</FONT>
	,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Entertainment&#8212;Films
</FONT>
	and ASC 605,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Revenue Recognition
</FONT>
	.&nbsp;&nbsp;We generate our revenue primarily from the exploitation of acquired or produced content rights through various distribution channels.&nbsp;&nbsp;The content is monetized in DVD format to wholesale, licensed to broadcasters including cable companies and digital platforms like Amazon and Netflix, and exploited through other windows including:&nbsp;&nbsp;video-on-demand, direct-to-consumer, catalogs and subscription streaming channels.&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenue is presented net of sales returns, rebates, unit price adjustments, sales return reserves, sales discounts and market development fund reserves.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Revenues from home video exploitation are recognized net of an allowance for estimated returns, as well as related costs, in the period in which the product is available for sale by our customers (at the point that title and risk of loss transfer to the customer, which is generally upon receipt by the customer and in the case of new releases, after &#8220;street date&#8221; restrictions lapse). Rental revenues under revenue sharing arrangements are recognized when we are entitled to receipts and such receipts are determinable.&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenues from domestic and international broadcast licensing and home video sublicensing, as well as associated costs, are recognized when the programming is available to the licensee and all other recognition requirements are met such as the broadcaster is free to air the programming.&nbsp;&nbsp;Fees received in advance of availability, usually in the case of advances received from international home video sub-licensees and for broadcast programming, are deferred until earned and all revenue recognition requirements have been satisfied.&nbsp;&nbsp;Provisions for sales returns and uncollectible accounts receivable are provided at the time of sale.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Revenues from our catalog sales are recognized net of an allowance for estimated returns once payment has been received from the customer and the item ordered has been shipped.&#160; Revenues from our proprietary, subscription-based, streaming channels are recognized on a straight-line basis over the subscription period once the subscription has been activated.&#160;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-LEFT:4.54%;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Allowances for Sales Returns
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	For each reporting period, we evaluate product sales and accounts receivable to estimate their effect on revenues due to product returns, sales allowances and other credits given, and delinquent accounts.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our estimates of product sales that will be returned and the amount of receivables that will ultimately be collected require the exercise of judgment and affect reported revenues and net earnings.&nbsp;&nbsp;In determining the estimate of product sales that will be returned, we analyze historical returns (quantity of returns and time to receive returned product), historical pricing and other credit data, current economic trends, and changes in customer demand and acceptance of our products, including reorder activity.&nbsp;&nbsp;Based on this information, we reserve a percentage of each dollar of product sales where the customer has the right to return such product and receive a credit.&nbsp;&nbsp;Actual returns could differ from our estimates and current provisions for sales returns and allowances, resulting in future charges to earnings.&nbsp;&nbsp;Estimates of future sales returns and other credits are subject to substantial uncertainty.&nbsp;&nbsp;Factors that could negatively impact actual returns include retailer financial difficulties, the perception of comparatively poor retail performance in one or several retailer locations, limited retail shelf space at various times of the year, inadequate advertising or promotions, retail prices being too high for the perceived quality of the content or other comparable content, the near-term release of similar titles, and poor responses to package designs.&nbsp;&nbsp;Underestimation of product sales returns and other credits would result in an overstatement of current revenues and lower revenues in future periods.&nbsp;&nbsp;Conversely, overestimation of product sales returns would result in an understatement of current revenues and higher revenues in future periods.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-LEFT:4.54%;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Allowances Received From Vendors
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	In accordance with ASC 605-50,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Revenue Recognition&#8212;Customer Payments and Incentives,
</FONT>
	we classify consideration received as a reduction in cost of sales in the accompanying statements of operations unless the consideration represents reimbursement of a specific, identifiable cost incurred by us in selling the vendor&#8217;s product.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	53
</P>
<HR STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS;WIDTH:100%;">
<A NAME="eolPage54"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-SIZE:1PT;">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-LEFT:4.54%;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
<A NAME="RLJE-10K_20151231_HTM__AEIOULASTRENDEREDPAGEBREAKAEIOU52">
</A>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Shipping Revenues and Expenses
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	In accordance with ASC 605-45,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Revenue Recognition&#8212;Principal Agent Considerations
</FONT>
	, we classify amounts billed to customers for shipping fees as revenues, and classify costs related to shipping as cost of sales in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-LEFT:4.54%;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Market Development Funds
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	In accordance with ASC 605-50,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Revenue Recognition&#8212;Customer Payment and Incentives
</FONT>
	, market development funds, including funds for specific product positioning, taken as a deduction from payment for purchases by customers are classified as a reduction to revenues.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Investments in Content
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Investments in content include the unamortized costs of completed films and television programs that were acquired or produced.&nbsp;&nbsp;Within the carrying balance of investments in content are development and production costs for films and television programs which are acquired or produced.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-LEFT:4.54%;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Acquired Distribution Rights and Produced Content
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Royalty and Distribution Fee Advances &#8211; Royalty and distribution fee advances represent fixed minimum payments made to program suppliers for exclusive content distribution rights.&nbsp;&nbsp;A program supplier&#8217;s share of exclusive program distribution revenues is retained by us until the share equals the advance(s) paid to the program supplier plus recoupable costs.&nbsp;&nbsp;Thereafter, any excess is paid to the program supplier.&nbsp;&nbsp;In the event of an excess, we also record, as cost of sales, an amount equal to the program supplier&#8217;s share of the net distribution revenues.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Original Production Costs &#8211; For films and television programs produced by RLJE, original production costs include all direct production and financing costs, as well as production overhead.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Unamortized content investments are charged to cost of sales as revenues are earned in the same ratio that current period revenue for a title or group of titles bears to the estimated remaining unrecognized ultimate revenue for that title.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Ultimate revenue includes estimates over a period not to exceed ten years following the date of initial release, or for episodic television series a period not to exceed 10 years from the date of delivery of the first episode or, if still in production, five years from the date of delivery of the most recent episode, if later.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Investments in content are stated at the lower of amortized cost or estimated fair value. The valuation of investments in content is reviewed on a title-by-title basis, when an event or change in circumstances indicates that the fair value of a film or television program is less than its unamortized cost. Additional amortization is recorded in the amount by which the unamortized costs exceed the estimated fair value of the film or television program.&nbsp;&nbsp;Estimates of future revenue involve measurement uncertainty and it is therefore possible that reductions in the carrying value of investment in films and television programs may be required as a consequence of changes in management&#8217;s future revenue estimates.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Content programs in progress include the accumulated costs of productions, which have not yet been completed, and advances on content not yet received from program suppliers. We begin to amortize these investments once the content has been released.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-LEFT:4.54%;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Production Development Costs
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	The costs to produce licensed content for domestic and international exploitation include the cost of converting film prints or tapes into the optical disc format.&nbsp;&nbsp;Depending on the platform for which the content is being exploited, costs may include menu design, authoring, compression, subtitling, closed captioning, service charges related to disc manufacturing, ancillary material production, product packaging design and related services.&nbsp;&nbsp;These costs are capitalized as incurred. A percentage of the capitalized production costs are amortized to expense based upon:&nbsp;&nbsp;(i) a projected revenue stream resulting from distribution of new and previously released content related to such production costs; and (ii) management&#8217;s estimate of the ultimate net realizable value of the production costs.&nbsp;&nbsp;Estimates of future revenues are reviewed periodically and amortization of production costs is adjusted accordingly.&nbsp;&nbsp;If estimated future revenues are not sufficient to recover the unamortized balance of production costs, such costs are reduced to their estimated fair value.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	54
</P>
<HR STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS;WIDTH:100%;">
<A NAME="eolPage55"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-SIZE:1PT;">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
<A NAME="RLJE-10K_20151231_HTM__AEIOULASTRENDEREDPAGEBREAKAEIOU53">
</A>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Inventories
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	For each reporting period, we review the value of inventories on hand to estimate the recoverability through future sales.&nbsp;&nbsp;Values in excess of anticipated future sales are recorded as obsolescence reserve.&nbsp;&nbsp;Inventories consist primarily of packaged goods for sale, which are stated at the lower-of-average-cost or market, as well as componentry.
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-LEFT:4.54%;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Goodwill
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Goodwill represents the excess of acquisition costs over the tangible and identifiable intangible assets acquired and liabilities assumed in a business acquisition.&nbsp;&nbsp;Goodwill is recorded at our reporting units, which are consolidated into our reporting segments.&nbsp;&nbsp;Goodwill is not amortized but is reviewed for impairment annually on October 1
<SUP STYLE="FONT-SIZE:85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN:TOP">
	st
</SUP>
	of each year or between the annual tests if an event occurs or circumstances change that indicates it is more-likely-than-not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying value.&nbsp;&nbsp;The impairment test follows a two-step approach.&nbsp;&nbsp;The first step determines if the goodwill is potentially impaired, and the second step measures the amount of the impairment loss, if necessary.&nbsp;&nbsp;Under the first step, goodwill is considered potentially impaired if there are subjective characteristics that suggest that goodwill is impaired or quantitatively when the fair value of the reporting unit is less than the reporting unit&#8217;s carry amount, including goodwill.&nbsp;&nbsp;Under the second step, the impairment loss is then measured as the excess of recorded goodwill over the fair value of the goodwill, as calculated.&nbsp;&nbsp;Determining the fair value requires various assumptions and estimates, which include consideration of the future, projected operating results and cash flows. Such projections could be different than actual results.&nbsp;&nbsp;Should actual results be significantly less than estimates, the value of our goodwill could be impaired in future periods.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	During 2015 and 2014, we recognized goodwill impairments of $30.3 million and $981,000, respectively (see Note 9,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets
</FONT>
	).
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-LEFT:4.54%;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Other Intangible Assets
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Other intangible assets are reported at their estimated fair value when acquired less accumulated amortization.&nbsp;&nbsp;The majority of our intangible assets were recognized as a result of the Business Combination.&nbsp;&nbsp;As such, the fair values of our intangibles were recorded in 2012 when applying purchase accounting.&nbsp;&nbsp;Additions since the 2012 Business Combination are limited to website expenditures.&nbsp;&nbsp;Similar to how we account for internal-use software development, costs incurred to develop and implement our websites are capitalized in accordance with ASC 350-50,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Website Development Costs
</FONT>
	.&nbsp;&nbsp;Website operating costs are expensed as incurred.&nbsp;&nbsp;Costs incurred for upgrades and enhancements that provide additional functionality are capitalized.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Amortization expense on our other intangible assets is generally computed by applying the straight-line method, or based on estimated forecasted future revenues as stated below, over the estimated useful lives of trade names (11 to 15 years), website (three years), supplier contracts (seven years), customer relationships (five years), options on future content (seven years) and leases (two years).&nbsp;&nbsp;The recorded value of our customer relationships is amortized on an accelerated basis over five years, with approximately 60% being amortized over the first two years (through 2014), 20% during the third year and the balance ratably over the remaining useful life.&nbsp;&nbsp;The recorded value of our options on future content is amortized based on forecasted future revenues, whereby approximately 50% is being amortized over the first two years (through 2014), 25% during the third year and the balance in decreasing amounts over the remaining four years.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Additional amortization expense is provided on an accelerated basis when the useful life of an intangible asset is determined to be less than originally expected.&nbsp;&nbsp;Other intangible assets are reviewed for impairment when an event or circumstance indicates the fair value is lower than the current carrying value.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	As described in Note 9,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets
</FONT>
	, during the third and fourth quarters of 2015, we recorded accelerated amortization expense totaling $1.3 million related to our brand name assets.&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2015 and 2014, we did not recognize any impairment on our other intangible assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Warrant and Other Derivative Liabilities
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	We have warrants outstanding to purchase 30.4 million shares of our common stock, which are recorded at fair value on the consolidated balance sheets (see Note 12,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Stock Warrants
</FONT>
	).&nbsp;&nbsp;Warrants issued in 2012 to acquire 21.0 million shares of common stock contain a provision whereby the exercise price will be reduced if RLJE is reorganized as a private company.&nbsp;&nbsp;Because of this provision, these warrants are accounted for as a derivative liability in accordance with ASC 815-40,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Contracts in Entity&#8217;s Own Equity
</FONT>
	.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
<A NAME="RLJE-10K_20151231_HTM__AEIOULASTRENDEREDPAGEBREAKAEIOU54">
</A>
	In May 2015, we issued additional warrants to acquire 9.3 million shares of our common stock.&nbsp;&nbsp;We are accounting for these warrants as a derivative liability because the warrants contain a provision that allows the warrant holders to sell their warrants back to
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	55
</P>
<HR STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS;WIDTH:100%;">
<A NAME="eolPage56"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-SIZE:1PT;">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	us, at their discretion, at a cash p
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	urchase price equal to the warrants&#8217; then fair value, upon the consummation of certain fundamental transactions, such as a business combination or other change-in-control transaction.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Our preferred stock is convertible into shares of common stock at an exchange rate equal to 1,000 shares of common stock for each share of preferred stock, subject to adjustment for any unpaid dividends.&nbsp;&nbsp;The conversion rate is also subject to anti-dilution protection including adjustments for offering consummated at a per-share price of less than $1.00 per common share.&nbsp;&nbsp;Because of the potential adjustments to the conversion rate, we have bifurcated the conversion feature from its host instrument (a preferred share) and we are accounting for the conversion feature as a derivative liability in accordance with ASC 815-40.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	The changes in the fair value of the warrants and bifurcated conversion feature are recorded as &#8220;Change in fair value of stock warrants and other derivatives&#8221; within our consolidated statements of operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Income Taxes
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	We account for income taxes pursuant to the provisions of ASC 740,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Income Taxes
</FONT>
	, whereby deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement carrying amount of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax bases and the future tax benefits derived from operating loss and tax credit carryforwards.&nbsp;&nbsp;We provide a valuation allowance on our deferred tax assets when it is more likely than not that such deferred tax assets will not be realized.&nbsp;&nbsp;We have a valuation allowance against 100% and 99% of our net deferred tax assets at December&#160;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	ASC 740 requires that we recognize in the consolidated financial statements the effect of a tax position that is more likely than not to be sustained upon examination based on the technical merits of the position.&nbsp;&nbsp;The first step is to determine whether or not a tax benefit should be recognized.&nbsp;&nbsp;A tax benefit will be recognized if the weight of available evidence indicates that the tax position is more likely than not to be sustained upon examination by the relevant tax authorities.&nbsp;&nbsp;The recognition and measurement of benefits related to our tax positions requires significant judgment as uncertainties often exist with respect to new laws, new interpretations of existing laws, and rulings by taxing authorities.&nbsp;&nbsp;Differences between actual results and our assumptions, or changes in our assumptions in future periods, are recorded in the period they become known.&nbsp;&nbsp;For tax liabilities, we recognize accrued interest related to uncertain tax positions as a component of income tax expense, and penalties, if incurred, are recognized as a component of operating expense.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Our foreign subsidiaries are subject to income taxes in their respective countries, as well as U.S. Federal and state income taxes. The income tax payments they make outside the U.S. give rise to foreign tax credits that we may use to offset taxable income in the United States.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Foreign Currency Translation
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	The consolidated financial statements are presented in our company&#8217;s functional and reporting currency, which is the U.S. dollar. For the foreign subsidiaries whose functional currency is other than the U.S. dollar (the British Pound Sterling or
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	GBP
</FONT>
	for RLJE U.K. and RLJE Ltd.; and Australian dollar for RLJE Australia), balance sheet accounts, other than equity accounts, are translated into U.S. dollars at exchange rates in effect at the end of the period and income statement accounts are translated at average monthly exchange rates.&nbsp;&nbsp;Equity accounts are translated at historical rates.&nbsp;&nbsp;Translation gains and losses are included as a separate component of equity.&nbsp;&nbsp;Gains and losses from foreign currency denominated transactions are included in the statement of operations as a component of other income (expense).
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Fair Value of Financial Instruments
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	The carrying amount of our financial instruments, which principally include cash, trade receivables, accounts payable and accrued expenses, approximates fair value due to the relative short maturity of such instruments.&nbsp;&nbsp;The carrying amount of our debt under our senior credit agreement approximates fair value as the debt bears market rates of interest.&nbsp;&nbsp;The carrying amount of our subordinated debt, which includes accrued interest, is $1.6 million more than its fair value of $7.9&#160;million as a result of its reduced interest rate from 12.0% to 1.5% for two years beginning January 1, 2015.&nbsp;&nbsp;The fair value of subordinated debt was determined by discounting future interest and principal payments by an estimated market rate of interest of 12.0%.&nbsp;&nbsp;This fair value assessment of our subordinated debt is a level 3 measurement as provided by ASC 820, &#8220;
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures.
</FONT>
	&#8221;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
<A NAME="RLJE-10K_20151231_HTM__AEIOULASTRENDEREDPAGEBREAKAEIOU55">
</A>
	ASC 820 defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value under U.S. GAAP and enhances disclosures about fair value measurements.&nbsp;&nbsp;Fair value is defined under ASC 820 as the exchange price that would be received for an asset or paid to transfer a liability (an exit price) in the principal or most advantageous market for the asset or liability in an orderly transaction between market participants on the measurement date. Valuation techniques used to measure fair value under ASC 820 must maximize the use of observable inputs and minimize the use of unobservable inputs.&nbsp;&nbsp;The standard describes a fair-value hierarchy
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	56
</P>
<HR STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS;WIDTH:100%;">
<A NAME="eolPage57"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-SIZE:1PT;">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	based on three levels of inputs, of which the first two are considered
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	observable and the last unobservable, that may be used to measure fair value as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Level 1
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;">
	&#8212;Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Level 2
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;">
	&#8212;Inputs other than Level 1 that are observable, either directly or indirectly, such as quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities; quoted prices in markets that are not active; or other inputs that are observable or can be corroborated by observable market data for substantially the full term of the assets or liabilities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Level 3
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;">
	&#8212;Unobservable inputs that are supported by little or no market activity and that are significant to the fair value of the assets or liabilities.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Our recurring fair value measurements of stock warrants and other derivative liabilities and our non-recurring fair value measurements of investments in content are disclosed in Note 15,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Fair Value Measurements
</FONT>
	.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our non-recurring fair value measurement of goodwill is disclosed in Note 9,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets
</FONT>
	.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Concentrations of Credit Risk
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Financial instruments which potentially subject RLJE to concentrations of credit risk consist primarily of deposit accounts and trade accounts receivable.&nbsp;&nbsp;RLJE maintains bank accounts at financial institutions, which at times may exceed amounts insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (or
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	FDIC
</FONT>
	) and Securities Investor Protection Corporation (or
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	SIPC
</FONT>
	).&nbsp;&nbsp;We place our cash with several financial institutions which are reputable and therefore bear minimal credit risk.&nbsp;&nbsp;RLJE has never experienced any losses related to these balances.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	With respect to trade receivables, we perform ongoing credit evaluations of our customers&#8217; financial conditions and limit the amount of credit extended when deemed necessary but generally require no collateral.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-LEFT:4.54%;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Major Customers and Distribution Facilitators
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	We have a high concentration of net revenues from relatively few customers, the loss of which may adversely affect our liquidity, business, results of operations, and financial condition.&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2015, sales reported within our wholesale segment to Amazon and Walmart represented 21.7% and 12.6%, respectively, of our net revenues.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our top five customers accounted for 54.8% of net revenues during the same period.&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2014, sales to Amazon accounted for 19.0% of our net revenues.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our top five customers accounted for approximately 46.2% of our net revenues for the same period.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	We may be unable to maintain favorable relationships with our retailers and distribution facilitators such as, Sony Pictures Home Entertainment (or
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	SPHE
</FONT>
	) and Sony DADC UK Limited.&nbsp;&nbsp;Further, our retailers and distribution facilitators may be adversely affected by economic conditions.&nbsp;&nbsp;If we lose any of our top customers, or if any of these customers reduces or cancels a significant order, it could have a material adverse effect on our liquidity, business, results of operations, and financial condition.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Our high concentration of sales to relatively few customers (and use of a third-party to manage collection of substantially all packaged goods receivables) may result in significant uncollectible accounts receivable exposure, which may adversely affect our liquidity, business, results of operations, and financial condition.&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&#160;31, 2015, SPHE and Netflix accounted for approximately 38.4% and 22.1%, respectively, of our gross accounts receivable.&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&#160;31, 2014, SPHE and Netflix accounted for approximately 44.0% and 21.4%, respectively, or our gross accounts receivable.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Property, Equipment and Improvements
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Property, equipment and improvements are stated at cost less accumulated depreciation and amortization.&nbsp;&nbsp;Major renewals and improvements are capitalized; minor replacements, maintenance and repairs are expensed as incurred.&nbsp;&nbsp;Internal-use software development costs are capitalized if the costs were incurred while in the application development stage, or if the costs were for upgrades and enhancements that provide additional functionality.&nbsp;&nbsp;Training and data-conversion costs are expensed as incurred.&nbsp;&nbsp;We cease capitalizing software costs and start depreciating the software once the project is substantially complete and ready for its intended use.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Depreciation and amortization are computed by applying the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the furniture, fixtures and equipment (3 to 7 years), and software (3 to 5 years).&nbsp;&nbsp;Leasehold improvements are amortized over the shorter of the useful life of the improvement or the life of the related leases (7 to 10 years).&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	57
</P>
<HR STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS;WIDTH:100%;">
<A NAME="eolPage58"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-SIZE:1PT;">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
<A NAME="RLJE-10K_20151231_HTM__AEIOULASTRENDEREDPAGEBREAKAEIOU56">
</A>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Impairment of Long-Lived Assets
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	We review long-lived and specific, definite-lived, identifiable intangible assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable.&nbsp;&nbsp;An impairment loss of the excess of the carrying value over fair value would be recognized when estimated undiscounted future cash flows expected to result from the use of the asset and its eventual disposition is less than its carrying amount.&nbsp;&nbsp;We have no intangible assets with indefinite useful lives.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Leases
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	We lease all of the office space utilized for our operations.&nbsp;&nbsp;All of our leases are operating leases in nature.&nbsp;&nbsp;A majority of our leases have fixed incremental increases over the lease terms, which are recognized on a straight-line basis over the term of the lease.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Equity Method Investments
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	We use the equity method of accounting for investments in companies in which we do not have voting control but where we do have the ability to exert significant influence over operating decisions of the companies.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our equity method investments are periodically reviewed to determine whether there has been a loss in value that is other than a temporary decline.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Debt Discounts
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	The difference between the principal amount of our debt and the amount recorded as the liability represents a debt discount.&nbsp;&nbsp;The carrying amount of the liability is accreted up to the principal amount through the amortization of the discount, using the effective interest method, to interest expense over the expected term of the debt.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Advertising Costs
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Our advertising expense consists of expenditures related to advertising in trade and consumer publications, product brochures and catalogs, booklets for sales promotion, radio advertising and other promotional costs.&nbsp;&nbsp;In accordance with ASC 720-35,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Other Expenses&#8212;Advertising Costs
</FONT>
	, and ASC 340-20,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Other Assets and Deferred Costs&#8212;Capitalized Advertising Costs
</FONT>
	, we expense advertising costs in the period in which the advertisement first takes place.&nbsp;&nbsp;Product brochures and catalogs and various other promotional costs are capitalized and amortized over the expected period of future benefit, but generally not exceeding six months.&nbsp;&nbsp;Advertising and promotion expense are included as a component of selling expenses.&nbsp;&nbsp;For the years ended December&#160;31, 2015 and 2014, advertising expense was $3.8 million and $3.3 million, respectively.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Stock Options and Restricted Stock Awards
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	We expense our stock-based awards in accordance with ASC 718,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Compensation&#8212;Stock Compensation
</FONT>
	.&nbsp;&nbsp;ASC&#160;718 establishes standards with respect to the accounting for transactions in which an entity exchanges its equity instruments for goods or services, or incurs liabilities in exchange for goods or services, that are based on the fair value of the entity&#8217;s equity instruments, focusing primarily on accounting for transactions in which an entity obtains employee services in share-based payment transactions.&nbsp;&nbsp;ASC&#160;718 requires entities to measure the cost of employee services received in exchange for an award of equity instruments based on the grant-date fair value of the award (with limited exceptions) and recognize the cost over the period during which an employee is required to provide service in exchange for the award.&nbsp;&nbsp;Expense recognized is reduced by estimated forfeitures.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Earnings/Loss per Common Share
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Basic earnings/loss per share is computed using the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding during the period.&nbsp;&nbsp;Diluted earnings per share are computed using the combination of dilutive common share equivalents and the weighted-average shares outstanding during the period.&nbsp;&nbsp;For the periods reporting a net loss, diluted loss per share is equivalent to basic loss per share, as inclusion of common share equivalents would be anti-dilutive.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:18PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Recently Issued Accounting Standards
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
<A NAME="RLJE-10K_20151231_HTM__AEIOULASTRENDEREDPAGEBREAKAEIOU57">
</A>
	On February 25, 2016 the Financial Accounting Standards Board (or
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	FASB
</FONT>
	) issued Accounting Standards Update (or
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	ASU
</FONT>
	) No. 2016&#8209;2,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Leases
</FONT>
	(the
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Update
</FONT>
	).&nbsp;&nbsp;The Update requires that most leases, including operating leases, be recorded on the balance sheet as an asset and a liability, initially measured at the present value of the lease payments.&nbsp;&nbsp;Subsequently, the lease asset will be amortized generally on a straight-line basis over the lease term, and the lease liability will bear interest expense and be reduced for lease payments.&nbsp;&nbsp;The amendments in this Update are effective for public companies&#8217; financial statements issued for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2018, including interim periods within those fiscal years.&nbsp;&nbsp;We will adopt this Update beginning January 1, 2019 by
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	58
</P>
<HR STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS;WIDTH:100%;">
<A NAME="eolPage59"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-SIZE:1PT;">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	applying a modified retroactive basis, which were are currently assessing.&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December 31, 2015, we have a numbe
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	r of operating leases that will be affected (see Note 21,
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Commitments and Contingencies
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	On April 7, 2015 the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update No. 2015&#8209;3,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Interest &#8211; Imputation of Interest
</FONT>
	(or
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	ASU 2015-3
</FONT>
	).&nbsp;&nbsp;ASU 2015-3 requires that debt issuance costs related to a recognized debt liability be presented in the balance sheet as a direct deduction from the carrying amount of that debt liability, consistent with debt discounts.&nbsp;&nbsp;The amendments in ASU 2015-3 are effective for financial statements issued for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2015, and interim periods within those fiscal years.&nbsp;&nbsp;We will adopt AUS 2015-3 beginning January 1, 2016 by applying the new guidance on a retroactive basis.&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&#160;31, 2015 and 2014, we have unamortized debt issuance costs of $832,000 and $1.2&#160;million, respectively that are currently recorded within prepaid expenses and other assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	On May 28, 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-09,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Revenue from Contracts with Customers
</FONT>
	(or
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	ASU 2014-09
</FONT>
	), which requires an entity to recognize the amount of revenue to which it expects to be entitled for the transfer of promised goods or services to customers.&nbsp;&nbsp;ASU 2014-09 will replace most existing revenue recognition guidance in U.S. GAAP when it becomes effective.&nbsp;&nbsp;The new standard is effective for RLJE on January 1, 2018.&nbsp;&nbsp;Early application is not permitted.&nbsp;&nbsp;The standard permits the use of one of three transition methods.&nbsp;&nbsp;We are evaluating the effect that ASU 2014-09 will have on our consolidated financial statements and related disclosures.&nbsp;&nbsp;We are also assessing the transition methods available to implement this new accounting standard.&nbsp;&nbsp;This update could impact the timing and amounts of revenue recognized within our consolidated financial statements.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	On August 27, 2014, the FASB issued ASU No. 2014-15,
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Presentation of Financial Statements &#8212; Going Concern
</FONT>
	(or
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	ASU 2014-15
</FONT>
	), which is intended to define management&#8217;s responsibility to evaluate whether there is substantial doubt about an organization&#8217;s ability to continue as a going concern and to provide related footnote disclosures.&nbsp;&nbsp;ASU 2014-15 provides guidance to an organization&#8217;s management, with principles and definitions that are intended to reduce diversity in the timing and content of disclosures that are commonly provided by organizations today in the financial statement footnotes.&nbsp;&nbsp;Under U.S. GAAP, financial statements are prepared under the presumption that the reporting organization will continue to operate as a going concern, except in limited circumstances.&nbsp;&nbsp;The going concern basis of accounting is critical to financial reporting because it establishes the fundamental basis for measuring and classifying assets and liabilities.&nbsp;&nbsp;Currently, U.S. GAAP lacks guidance about management&#8217;s responsibility to evaluate whether there is substantial doubt about the organization&#8217;s ability to continue as a going concern or to provide related footnote disclosures.
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:11PT;TEXT-TRANSFORM:UPPERCASE;">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
	We will adopt this ASU beginning with our annual period ending December 31, 2016, and interim periods within annual periods beginning after December 15, 2016.&nbsp;&nbsp;Upon adoption, we will begin evaluating going concern under this guidance.
</P>
<P STYLE="BACKGROUND-COLOR:#FFFFFF;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-SIZE:9PT;">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-LEFT:10.27%;TEXT-INDENT:-10.27%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<DIV ALIGN="LEFT">
<TABLE BORDER="0" CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; WIDTH:100%;">
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="WIDTH:10.27%;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN BOLD;TEXT-TRANSFORM:UPPERCASE;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN BOLD;TEXT-TRANSFORM:UPPERCASE;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Note 3.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;TEXT-TRANSFORM:UPPERCASE;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN BOLD;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
	Segment Information
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:6PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	In accordance with the requirements of the ASC 280 &#8220;
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Segment Reporting,
</FONT>
	&#8221; selected financial information regarding our reportable business segments, IP Licensing, Wholesale and Direct-to-Consumer, is presented below.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our reportable segments are determined based on the distinct nature of their operation.&nbsp;&nbsp;Each segment is a strategic business unit that is managed separately and either exploits our content over a different customer base or acquires content differently.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our IP Licensing segment includes intellectual property (or
<FONT STYLE="FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	content
</FONT>
	) owned or created by us, other than certain fitness related content, that is licensed for exploitation worldwide.&nbsp;&nbsp;The IP Licensing segment also includes our investment in ACL.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Wholesale segment consists of the acquisition, enhancement and worldwide exploitation of exclusive content in various formats, including DVD, Blu-ray, digital, broadcast (including cable and satellite), VOD, streaming video, downloading and sublicensing.&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Direct-to-Consumer segment consists of our mail-order catalog and ecommerce businesses and our proprietary digital streaming channels.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Management currently evaluates segment performance based primarily on revenues and operating income (loss), including earnings from ACL.&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating costs and expenses attributable to our Corporate segment include only those expenses incurred by us at the parent corporate level, which are not allocated to our reporting segments and include costs associated with RLJE&#8217;s corporate functions such as finance and accounting, human resources, legal and information technology departments.&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest expense, change in the fair value of stock warrants and other derivatives, other income (expense) and provision for income taxes are evaluated by management on a consolidated basis and are not allocated to our reportable segments.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	59
</P>
<HR STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-AFTER:ALWAYS;WIDTH:100%;">
<A NAME="eolPage60"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-SIZE:1PT;">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
<A NAME="RLJE-10K_20151231_HTM__AEIOULASTRENDEREDPAGEBREAKAEIOU58">
</A>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	The following tab
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	les summarize the segment contribution for the years ended December&#160;31, 2015 and 2014:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	&#160;
</P>

	Direct-to-
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-LEFT:0PT;;TEXT-INDENT:0PT;;COLOR:#000000;FONT-SIZE:8PT;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Consumer
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF" STYLE="PADDING-LEFT:0PT;PADDING-RIGHT:0.75PT;PADDING-TOP:0.75PT;WIDTH:1%; BORDER-BOTTOM:SOLID 0.75PT TRANSPARENT;WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP;">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-LEFT:0PT;;TEXT-INDENT:0PT;;COLOR:#000000;FONT-SIZE:8PT;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	&nbsp;

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:2PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Operating costs and expenses exclude costs related to depreciation and amortization, as well as goodwill impairments, which are separately presented in the tables above.&nbsp;&nbsp;Included in our Wholesale segment contribution for the year ended December 31, 2014 is a loss of $3.1 million incurred during the sell-off period under a terminated feature film content output deal that was recognized in the first quarter of 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Despite generating revenues in excess of $10.0 million for each of the past two years, the Acacia catalog, which is included in our Direct-to-Consumer segment, has not secured a large enough market share to become profitable. The health and fitness sector has become increasingly competitive and digital in nature, thereby reducing opportunities for merchandise cross and up-selling.&nbsp;&nbsp;Management has therefore decided to exit the Acacia catalog and online business and focus on distributing Acacia content through RLJE&#8217;s third-party wholesale channels and its direct-to-consumer SVOD service Acacia TV.&nbsp;&nbsp;For the years ended December&#160;31, 2015 and 2014, Acacia catalog net revenues were $11.1 million and $13.3&#160;million, respectively.&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant operating costs and expenses consist of cost of goods sold and selling expense, which include advertising and marketing costs, catalog expenses and postage.&nbsp;&nbsp;As a percentage of revenues, these significant expenses were 128% and 108% of revenues for 2015 and 2014, respectively.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Acacia catalog generated operating losses, which are included in segment contribution, of $4.0&#160;million and $1.8&#160;million for the years ended December 31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	A reconciliation of total segment contribution (loss) to loss before provision for income taxes is as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	&#160;
</P>

<TR>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" BGCOLOR="#FFFFFF" STYLE="PADDING-LEFT:0PT;PADDING-RIGHT:0.75PT;PADDING-TOP:0.75PT;WIDTH:66.98%; BORDER-BOTTOM:SOLID 0.75PT TRANSPARENT;">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-LEFT:0PT;;TEXT-INDENT:0PT;;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;COLOR:#000000;FONT-SIZE:8PT;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	(In thousands)
</P>

	Revenues are attributed to geographical locations based on where our customers reside.
<FONT STYLE="FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Total assets for each segment primarily include accounts receivable, inventory and investments in content.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Corporate segment primarily includes assets not fully allocated to a segment including consolidated cash accounts, certain prepaid assets and fixed assets used across all segments.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:2PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	During the year ended December&#160;31, 2015, we had capital expenditures of $1.6 million, which includes $76,000 that was accrued for in accounts payable.&nbsp;&nbsp;The capital expenditures by segment during 2015 were $112,000, $682,000, $548,000 and $239,000 for the IP Licensing, Wholesale, Direct-to-Consumer and Corporate segments, respectively.&nbsp;&nbsp;During the year ended December&#160;31, 2014, we had capital expenditures of $2.0&#160;million, which includes $300,000 that was accrued for in accounts payable.&nbsp;&nbsp;The capital expenditures by segment during 2014 were $437,000, $716,000, $437,000 and $365,000 for the IP&#160;Licensing, Wholesale, Direct-to-Consumer and Corporate segments, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:12PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Long-lived assets by geographical location are as follows:
</P>

	&#160;

<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;">

<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-TOP:2PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:4.54%;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;FONT-SIZE:10PT;FONT-WEIGHT:NORMAL;FONT-STYLE:NORMAL;TEXT-TRANSFORM:NONE;FONT-VARIANT: NORMAL;">
	Long-lived assets include goodwill, other intangibles assets, equity investment in ACL, investments in content and property, equipment and improvements.&nbsp;&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-SIZE:9PT;">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;TEXT-INDENT:0%;FONT-SIZE:9PT;">
	&nbsp;
